top_categories.workout_context: 50ft/mi means long efforts at or near FTP on every climb. If your threshold cracks at minute 15, you'll walk the rest.
Nicolet Hot Days' Wisconsin rolling, Local event forces constant power changes. Surge over the rough stuff, settle on the smooth, repeat for 50 miles.
At Nicolet Hot Days, surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding. Over-unders train exactly that.
88–92% FTP is where you'll spend the hardest sustained miles of Nicolet Hot Days. Train it until it feels boring.
Race-pace efforts that mimic Nicolet Hot Days' demands. Pacing, fueling, and tactical decisions under fatigue. Practice the race before August.
50 miles on Wisconsin rolling gravel burns energy faster than the distance suggests. Train the fade resistance now.
Varied gradients on Wisconsin rolling gravel demand climbing versatility. Sit the shallow stuff, stand the steep stuff, switch without thinking.
When someone attacks on Wisconsin rolling gravel, you have 10 seconds to respond or you're off the back. This builds that response.
How long can you hold 105% FTP before you blow? At Nicolet Hot Days, that number decides whether you bridge or get dropped.
Double-threshold training builds sustained power with less fatigue. More FTP per hour of training.
Base fitness for Nicolet Hot Days. Without this, the hard workouts break you down instead of building you up.
Torque for headwinds and Wisconsin rolling gravel. When cadence drops below 70rpm, muscular strength keeps the watts up.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 40–60g carbs/hour for Nicolet Hot Days’s 50 miles. Front-load calories in the first half. One bottle per hour minimum, more in heat.
race_overlay.terrain: Mixed terrain at Nicolet Hot Days requires surface adaptability. Include weekly rides on wisconsin rolling gravel to build confidence. Expect: wisconsin rolling, local event, midwest gravel.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on TT Threshold, Gravel Specific, and Over Under to prepare you for 50 miles of wisconsin rolling gravel in Wabeno, Wisconsin.
